Remove the picture and if a pic is requested then add a professional one.
Put the career objectives at the top of the CV ..and personal skills and interest at the end ...
Remove the repeated words "responsible for... " and write what you did directly  "developed xyz , maintained abc, ....etc"

1 - Change / remove your resume photo
2 - remove personal skills, interests and career summary
3 - your cv sections should be ordered like that 
- Personal Information
- Career Objective
- Skills
- Experience
- University Degree
- anything else
4 - you CV pages max should be 3 - 4 pages!
5 - try to find bench mark CV close to your skills and try to simulate
and change the page size to A4 please
8 ØµÙØ­Ø§Øª Ù…Ø´ Ù‡ØªØªÙØªØ­

I agree with what Sara El-Kady said; and I'd like to add the following: Your CV should only include relevent information; you're expected to have analytical skills and problem solving skills - to different degrees of proficiency -, and as a software engineer, you're fully expected to know SDLC; they don't want to know what they already know; they are interested to know what knowledge do you currently have, and what have you accomplished in your previous/current roles. This gives them, with evidence, information that relates to your skills and performance in your previous jobs. Always remember that people who check CVs are not going to be looking at your CV long; they will take from 30 seconds to 3 minutes to screen your CV; if they find a lot of irrelevent information, that can turn them off; look for what might grab their attention, while emphasizing on the skills you want to tell them about. After they call you with an interview, that's your chance to tell them more about your skills and how you utilized them to achieve these accomplishments in your CV. That's my personal opinion, and good luck. :)

Try to quantify (in percentage or numbers)  how much your skills increase the performance of your company or software. Also, know the difference between the resumee and CV. Finally, create an online portfolio and It would better if you add other activities not related to programming or IT. And, as many suggested don't include your picture in the resumee.

a recruiter told me to reshape my cv to make it near from this template
https://drive.google.com/file/d/0B8jd5MlcJs-IYThlbWsyRmpCS2M/view?usp=sharing
good luck

Here is my honest opinion: You specified no projects at all. And for each job title it was like a copy and paste job. So your  resume tells me absolutely NOTHING. Usually people exaggerate their resume, but this resume has no links to code or projects at all and saying that you were responsible for requirements analysis in a copy and paste manner tells me that this is not true. NOTE: I might seem a little harsh, but I was looking at the resume with a critiquing eye and immediatley what I saw brought about negative emotions because I usually play a role in filtering resumes, this one tells me that you did a copy and paste job and exaggerated
Points to improve: Projects, Githib repository with your code, Design patterns, no copy and paste accross job responsibilities
